questions.text: Pre-malignant condition of the skin include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Acanthosis nigricans is not considered a pre-malignant skin lesion. While it can be associated with internal malignancies (especially gastric adenocarcinoma in its malignant form), it is more accurately described as a paraneoplastic syndrome rather than a direct precursor to skin cancer.

True pre-malignant skin conditions include:

  • Actinic (solar) keratosis: precursor to squamous cell carcinoma (Option B ruled out)
  • Bowen's disease: squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Option D ruled out)
  • Cutaneous horns, arsenical keratoses, and keratoacanthoma (though the latter is sometimes considered a variant of squamous cell carcinoma)
  • Leukoplakia: Often considered premalignant, particularly in mucosal sites (e.g. oral cavity) (Option A ruled out).
  • Giant congenital melanocytic nevus and dysplastic nevus: Premalignant for malignant melanoma

Actinic keratosis

Bowen's disease

Cutaneous horn

Keratoacanthoma

Dysplastic nevus

Giant congenital melanocytic nevus

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with a 10-year history of persistent, scaly patches on his trunk and upper thighs. Examination reveals erythematous hyperpigmented large plaques on the flanks and buttocks with overlying fine scales. Some lesions exhibit a reticular pattern. Which of the following malignancies is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with large-plaque parapsoriasis, a chronic dermatosis that resembles psoriasis but is considered a potential precursor to cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL)-particularly mycosis fungoides, the most common type of CTCL.

  • Large-plaque parapsoriasis typically involves persistent, scaly, erythematous to hyperpigmented plaques located on the flanks, buttocks, and proximal thighs.
  • The lesions may exhibit a retiform or poikilodermatous pattern.
  • The latency period before malignant transformation can span years to decades (up to 40 years).
  • Regular follow-up and biopsies are required due to the risk of progression to mycosis fungoides.

Explanation of other options:

Basal cell carcinoma (Option A): BCC is the most common skin cancer, usually presenting as a pearly papule with telangiectasia on sun-exposed areas (face, neck). It does not arise from chronic dermatoses like parapsoriasis and is not associated with large plaques or a scaly retiform pattern.

Melanoma (Option C): Melanoma arises from melanocytes and typically presents as an asymmetric pigmented lesion with irregular borders, often following the ABCDE rule. It is unrelated to parapsoriasis and its presentation differs significantly from the plaques seen here.

Merkel cell carcinoma (Option D): This is a rare, aggressive neuroendocrine skin cancer that presents as a rapidly growing firm, red-to-violet nodule, often on sun-exposed areas in older adults. It is not linked to parapsoriasis or chronic plaque disorders.

questions.text: A 68-year-old retired farmer presents to your clinic with multiple rough, scaly patches on his face and the dorsal aspects of both hands. He reports no pain or itching, but mentions that the lesions have been present for several months and feel like 'sandpaper.' He has a history of extensive sun exposure over several decades without consistent use of sun protection. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Actinic keratosis is a premalignant condition resulting from chronic UV exposure, particularly in individuals with fair skin.
  • It typically presents on sun-exposed areas like the scalp, face, and hands as rough, scaly, erythematous or brownish lesions.
  • The "sandpaper" texture is characteristic.
  • These lesions can potentially progress to squamous cell carcinoma if left untreated.

Explanation of other options:

Seborrheic keratosis (Option B): A benign, pigmented epidermal tumor often seen in the elderly. It is not related to sun exposure and has a "stuck-on" appearance.

Sebaceous cell carcinoma (Option C): Rare, aggressive malignancy typically arising from Meibomian glands of eyelids, with no established direct link to UV exposure.

Syringomas (Option D): Benign adnexal tumours derived from eccrine sweat glands, commonly found around the eyes. They have no known link to sun exposure.

questions.text: The most common premalignant tumour of the skin is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Actinic keratosis (also known as solar keratosis or keratosis senilis) is the most common premalignant skin lesion. It results from chronic exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation, particularly in fair-skinned individuals with significant sun exposure.

Clinical features

  • Rough, scaly, erythematous papules or plaques
  • Commonly seen on sun-exposed areas: face, scalp, dorsal hands, and forearms
  • May be tender or asymptomatic
  • Lesions have a risk of progression to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Histopathology:

  • Atypical keratinocytes confined to the lower third of the epidermis
  • Solar elastosis in the dermis indicating chronic UV damage

Explanation of other options:

Bowen's disease (Option A): A premalignant condition but less common; it is SCC in situ

Arsenical keratosis (Option C): Premalignant, but relatively rare and associated with chronic arsenic exposure

Buschke-Löwenstein tumour (Option D): A giant condyloma caused by HPV; considered a low-grade malignant tumour, not premalignant.

questions.text: A 2-day-old male neonate is examined during a routine newborn check. The paediatrician observes the following large, darkly pigmented patch with coarse terminal hairs covering the chest and trunk. There are no neurological deficits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and is known to carry a risk of malignant transformation into melanoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Giant congenital melanocytic naevus (GCMN) is a pigmented lesion present at birth that carries a significant risk of malignant transformation into melanoma, especially during childhood.

Key points:

  • Classification by size:
    • Small: <1.5 cm
    • Medium: 1.5–20 cm
    • Large: 20–40 cm
    • Giant: >40 cm (or covering >2% of body surface area in infants)
  • Malignant potential:
    • The risk of melanoma increases with the size of the naevus.
    • Giant CMN has the highest risk of melanoma and may also be associated with neurocutaneous melanosis (melanocytic infiltration of the CNS).
  • Appearance:
    Often described as having a "garment-like" distribution, such as a "bathing trunk" or "coat sleeve" pattern.

Incorrect options explained:

Giant Mongolian spot (Option A): A benign dermal melanocytosis with no malignant potential.

Naevus of Ota (Option B): Pigmented lesion involving the face and eye; rarely associated with melanoma

Halo naevus (Option D): A pigmented mole surrounded by a depigmented ring; typically benign and sometimes associated with autoimmune activity.

Giant Mongolian spot

Naevus of Ota

Halo naevus

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a chronic, itchy skin eruption that has been slowly evolving over several years. On examination, he has multiple erythematous to violaceous scaly patches and plaques, some with atrophy, distributed over the trunk and proximal extremities. There is no mucosal involvement or systemic symptoms. A skin biopsy is performed, and on histopathological examination, the following is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Mycosis fungoides is the most common variant of primary cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) and typically has a slow, indolent course, especially in the early patch and plaque stages.

Clinical Features:

  • Presents with polymorphic skin lesions: erythematous patches, plaques, and eventually tumours
  • Distribution often includes the limbs, girdle area, breasts, and especially the buttocks
  • Frequently shows a "bathing trunk" pattern
  • Lesions may be misdiagnosed as eczema or psoriasis early on

Patch

Plaque

Nodule/tumour

Histopathology:

  • Hallmark cells: Sézary-Lutzner cells, which are atypical CD4+ helper T cells with cerebriform (brain-like) nuclei
  • Epidermotropism: These malignant T cells migrate into the epidermis
  • Pautrier microabscesses: Clusters of these atypical lymphocytes within the epidermis
  • Unlike psoriasis or dermatitis herpetiformis, the infiltrate is lymphocytic, not neutrophilic

Explanation of other options:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option A):

  • Shows neutrophilic microabscesses at dermal papillae tips
  • Strongly associated with celiac disease

Psoriasis (Option B):

  • Exhibits Munro's microabscesses (neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Kogoj's pustules (neutrophils in stratum spinosum)
  • Typically does not show epidermotropism or lymphocytic microabscesses

Pityriasis lichenoides chronica (Option D):

  • Shows a mixed lymphocytic infiltrate, but not well-formed intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscesses
  • Lesions are smaller and more transient

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with longstanding, scaly, erythematous patches and thin plaques over the trunk and thighs. No lymphadenopathy or systemic symptoms. Biopsy shows epidermotropic atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei and Pautrier microabscesses. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

This is early-stage cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), likely Stage IB, based on:

  • Patches and plaques covering ≥10% of the body surface
  • No lymph node, blood, or visceral involvement

First-line treatment for Stage IA/IB includes skin-directed therapies such as:

  • PUVA (Psoralen + UVA phototherapy) - most effective for widespread disease
  • Topical corticosteroids
  • Narrow-band UVB (alternative, especially in lighter skin)

Systemic options like biological agents, photopheresis, or chemotherapy are reserved for advanced stages (IIB-IV).

Total Skin Electron Beam Therapy (TSEBT) is a specialized form of radiation therapy that can be used particularly in the advanced patch, plaque, or tumor stages

Explanation of other options:

Biological response modifiers (Option B): (e.g., interferon-alpha, retinoids): used in more advanced or refractory cases

Systemic chemotherapy (Option C): reserved for late-stage (tumor stage or blood/lymph node involvement)

Extracorporeal photopheresis (Option D): typically used in Sézary syndrome or Stage IV CTCL with blood involvement

questions.text: All of the following are paraneoplastic conditions except
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Acrochordons (skin tags) are benign skin growths with no established association with malignancy. They are linked to obesity, insulin resistance, and metabolic syndrome, not cancer

Explanation of other options:

Tripe palms (Option A): Characterized by thickened, velvety palms with exaggerated dermatoglyphics. Strongly associated with gastric adenocarcinoma and lung cancer.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option C): Neutrophilic dermatosis associated with systemic diseases, including hematological malignancies like leukemia, multiple myeloma, and myelodysplastic syndromes.

Dermatomyositis (Option D): An idiopathic inflammatory myopathy often associated with underlying malignancy, especially ovarian, lung, pancreatic, and gastric cancers.

choices.text: Most common site are neck and axilla
Possible role for insulin like growth factor in the etiology

questions.text: Not true about the dermatoses shown in the image below -
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The lesions described are skin tags (also known as acrochordons), which are common benign skin neoplasms. They are:

  • Often associated with obesity, diabetes mellitus, and acanthosis nigricans. (Option A ruled out)
  • Most commonly found in intertriginous areas such as the neck, axillae, and inguinal folds. (Option B ruled out)
  • Soft, pedunculated lesions, varying in color from skin-toned to hyperpigmented.
  • A possible role of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) in their pathogenesis has been suggested (Option C ruled out)

Treatment options include:

  • Cautery
  • Cryotherapy
  • Snipping (scissor excision)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a firm lesion on his face that has been present for the past 3 years, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The diagnosis of Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is suggested by the following:

  • Chronic, slow-growing lesion on a sun-exposed area (face)
  • Pigmented variant of BCC can appear dark, mimicking melanoma
  • Characteristic features seen in the image:
    • Rolled, raised border
    • Shiny/translucent surface
    • Firm nodule with possible central depression or ulceration
  • No signs of asymmetry, color variation, or rapid evolution typically seen in melanoma

(BCC) is the most common skin cancer, especially in elderly individuals and in sun-exposed areas like the face.

Key features of BCC:

  • Typically appears as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule.
  • May have prominent telangiectasia.
  • Pigmented BCC contains melanin, giving it a darker appearance that may resemble malignant melanoma.
  • However, it can be distinguished by:
    • Translucent surface
    • Rolled, raised borders
    • Firm consistency
    • Occasional central ulceration

Subtypes of BCC:

  • Nodular: Most common: presents as a pearly papule or nodule with central ulcer and telangiectasia
  • Superficial: Scaly, red patch or plaque, often on the trunk; may resemble eczema or psoriasis
  • Pigmented: Contains melanin, may mimic melanoma; common in darker skin types
  • Morpheaform (Sclerosing): Scar-like, ill-defined, and more aggressive with deep infiltration
  • Basosquamous: Mixed features of BCC and SCC; more aggressive, higher risk of recurrence

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Often presents as a firm, hyperkeratotic plaque or nodule with potential for central ulceration. It tends to be more aggressive than BCC.

Malignant melanoma (Option C): Characterised by the ABCDE criteria (Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Colour variation, Diameter >6mm, Evolution).

Melanoacanthoma (Option D): A rare, benign pigmented lesion, generally considered a variant of seborrheic keratosis.

Explanation for the answer:

Gorlin syndrome (also known as Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome or NBCCS) is directly associated with the development of multiple, early-onset basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) — often arising in sun-protected areas and during childhood or adolescence, unlike sporadic BCC, which appears later in sun-exposed areas.

Key Features:

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Genetic mutation: Mutations in the PTCH1 gene, a tumor suppressor located on chromosome 9q.
    • PTCH1 encodes a receptor in the sonic hedgehog (SHH) signaling pathway, critical for embryonic development and tumor suppression.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas (BCCs)
    • Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., bifid ribs, jaw cysts)
    • Ophthalmologic and neurologic anomalies
    • Increased risk of medulloblastoma (especially in children)

Treatment Options for BCCs in Gorlin Syndrome:

  • Surgical:
    • Curettage and electrodessication
    • Cryosurgery
    • Surgical excision
    • Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS)
  • Topical therapies:
    • 5% 5-fluorouracil (5-FU)
    • 5% imiquimod
    • Photodynamic therapy (PDT)
  • Systemic therapy:
    • Vismodegib - a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that targets the smoothened (SMO) receptor; approved for treating advanced or multiple BCCs in Gorlin syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A): Not characteristically seen in Gorlin syndrome

Malignant melanoma (Option C): Not genetically linked to PTCH1 mutation

Merkel cell carcinoma (Option D): Rare, aggressive neuroendocrine cancer, unrelated to NBCCS

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a lesion on the face. He reports that it tends to bleed when scratched. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The lesion shows several classic features of basal cell carcinoma (BCC):

  • Location: Commonly on sun-exposed areas, particularly the face
  • Appearance:
    • Pearly or translucent surface
    • Rolled, raised edges
    • Central ulcer or depression
  • Symptom: The lesion bleeds on minor trauma, such as scratching - a hallmark of BCC
  • Growth: Slow-growing and persistent, often over months or years

These features strongly suggest nodular BCC, the most common subtype.

  • It is the most common skin cancer, especially in elderly individuals with chronic sun exposure (e.g., face, nose, ears)
  • Often referred to as a "rodent ulcer" in later stages due to local tissue destruction

Subtypes of BCC:

  • Nodular: Most common, presents as a pearly papule or nodule with central ulcer and telangiectasia
  • Superficial: Scaly, red patch or plaque, often on the trunk; may resemble eczema or psoriasis
  • Pigmented: Contains melanin, may mimic melanoma; common in darker skin types
  • Morpheaform (Sclerosing): Scar-like, ill-defined, and more aggressive with deep infiltration
  • Basosquamous: Mixed features of BCC and SCC; more aggressive, higher risk of recurrence

Incorrect options explained:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (Option B): More likely to present as a keratotic or crusted nodule or ulcer; faster growing, and more likely to metastasise than BCC.

Malignant melanoma (Option C): Typically asymmetrical pigmented lesions with color variation, irregular borders, and history of change; bleeding is not a hallmark feature early on.

Mycosis fungoides (Option D): A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents as chronic scaly patches or plaques, not usually with ulceration or bleeding on scratching.

choices.text: Immunohistochemistry for clonal rearrangement of the T-cell receptor genes.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with erythematous scaly skin lesions on the trunk for 4 -5 years. A skin biopsy was done, and the findings are shown below. Which further test will help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient’s chronic course of scaly, erythematous patches over the trunk in an older adult, combined with the histopathological findings, is strongly suggestive of Mycosis Fungoides (MF), the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL).

Histopathology shows:

  • Epidermotropism: Infiltration of atypical lymphocytes into the epidermis
  • Pautrier’s microabscesses: Small collections of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis
  • Band-like infiltrate of lymphocytes in the superficial dermis

These features are characteristic of early CTCL, especially patch or plaque stage MF.

  • CTCL is a primary cutaneous lymphoma of T-cell origin.
  • Mycosis fungoides is the most common subtype.
  • Immunophenotype: CD2+, CD3+, CD4+, CD5+, CD45RO+
  • Clinical stages: 3
    • Patch stage: The earliest lesion seen in mycosis fungoides is an erythematous, or brownish, scaly patch
    • Plaque stage:In the plaque stage, lesions now appear larger and raised with evident infiltration, along with the appearance of new lesions
    • Tumour stage: In the tumor stage, erythematous-purplish papules or nodules of larger diameter are seen.
    • The frequency of lymph nodal or visceral dissemination increases as the lesions progress from the patch stage to the plaque stage and finally the tumor stage.
    • Sezary syndrome is the final end stage and is characterized by a triad of manifestations: erythroderma with pruritus, lymphadenopathy, and atypical circulating lymphocytes (referred to as Sezary or Lutzner cells). The syndrome is understood as a leukemic phase of T-cell cutaneous lymphoma.

Why Immunohistochemistry for T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement?

  • Confirms monoclonality, a hallmark of malignancy
  • Helps differentiate CTCL from benign inflammatory dermatoses, which show polyclonal T-cell populations

Explanation of other options:

Patch test (Option B): for allergic contact dermatitis, not useful in suspected CTCL

KOH scraping (Option C): rules out fungal infections, not relevant here

Serum IgE (Option D): elevated in atopic dermatitis, parasitic infections, but nonspecific

choices.text: A hamartoma of eccrine sweat gland

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presented with asymptomatic lesions around the eye. What is the pathology of this disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical description suggests syringoma, a benign adnexal tumor most commonly affecting young women, particularly around the periorbital area.

Key points:

  • Syringoma is a hamartomatous proliferation of the eccrine sweat ducts, specifically showing differentiation toward the acrosyringium (the intraepidermal part of the sweat duct).
  • Histologically, it shows small ducts embedded in a fibrous stroma, often described as having a "comma-shaped" or "tadpole-like" appearance.
  • Lesions are typically flesh-colored, small, and asymptomatic, and commonly symmetrical around the eyelids.

Explanation of other options:

Cyst of pilosebaceous apparatus (Option B): Suggests epidermoid or sebaceous cyst, usually not limited to the periorbital area and often larger, dome-shaped.

Epidermal keratinous cyst (Option C): Represents an epidermoid cyst, commonly found on the trunk, face, or scalp but typically not periorbital and contains keratin.

Accumulation of fat cells (Option D): May refer to lipomas, which are subcutaneous, soft, and not typically clustered around the eyes

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with the following lesion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion displays classic features of malignant melanoma, based on the ABCDE criteria:

  • A - Asymmetry
  • B - Border irregularity
  • C - Color variation
  • D - Diameter: Although not measured here, the lesion is clearly large.
  • E - Evolution: While not mentioned explicitly, the pigmentation and spread over mucosa suggest malignant progression.

In addition, the mucosal involvement, which is less common in benign lesions, and nodularity (seen in dermoscopic close-up images), further support the diagnosis of melanoma, possibly of the mucocutaneous or acral lentiginous type, which is more common in darker-skinned individuals

  • Melanoma is a malignant neoplasm of melanocytes. Though it accounts for only ~4% of skin cancers, it causes ~80% of skin cancer-related deaths due to its aggressive nature and metastatic potential.
  • Common in sun-exposed areas, especially in fair-skinned individuals
  • Often arises de novo (in 75-80% of cases), not necessarily from a pre-existing nevus

Explanation of other options:

Seborrhoeic keratosis (Option A): Waxy, stuck-on appearance; often uniform in color and benign

Lentigo (Option B): Flat, uniformly pigmented macule-does not show irregularity or nodularity

Basal cell carcinoma (Option D): Typically presents as a pearly or translucent papule with telangiectasia and may ulcerate ("rodent ulcer"), but lacks the color variegation seen in melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic clue used to assess the malignant transformation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The ABCD criteria are widely used for the early recognition of malignant melanoma:

  • A - Asymmetry: One half of the lesion does not match the other.
  • B - Border irregularity: Edges are ragged, notched, or blurred.
  • C - Colour variation: Multiple shades (brown, black, red, blue, or white) within the lesion.
  • D - Diameter: Lesions larger than 6 mm are more suspicious.

Additionally, E - Evolution (or change over time) has been added in the ABCDE extension, which includes growth, bleeding, itching, or any new symptom.
